title: Judgment on Nineveh
shortSummary: Nahum chapter 3 pronounces a vivid and severe judgment against the city of Nineveh, the capital of Assyria, for its violence, idolatry, and moral corruption. The chapter uses powerful imagery to depict the city's downfall and serves as a warning of God's righteous wrath against sin and oppression.
timeline: c. 7th century BC - Assyrian Empire's decline before Babylonian conquest

keyCharacters.name: Nineveh
keyCharacters.description: The capital city of Assyria, personified as a corrupt and violent 'bloody city' subject to God's judgment.

keyCharacters.name: LORD of hosts
keyCharacters.description: God who declares His opposition to Nineveh and announces its coming destruction.

definitions.definition: Metaphorical term for spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry, often describing a nation’s betrayal of God through alliances and false worship.
Practices of sorcery or occult arts; here symbolizing deceptive and corrupt political or spiritual manipulation.
An object of public scorn and ridicule; one exposed to shame before all.
A destructive insect used metaphorically for an unstoppable force of judgment consuming everything in its path.

outline.heading: Woe to the Bloody City and Its Corruption
outline.description: The chapter opens with a lament over Nineveh’s violence, lies, and robbery, describing the city as a harlot who corrupts nations through idolatry and witchcraft. God declares His judgment and exposes her shame before the nations.

outline.heading: The Coming Destruction and Shame of Nineveh
outline.description: God promises to make Nineveh vile and a spectacle of shame, recalling the fate of Thebes, a once-powerful city that was conquered despite its strength and allies.

outline.heading: The Futility of Nineveh’s Defenses
outline.description: Despite efforts to fortify and prepare for siege, Nineveh’s strongholds will fall easily, her people will be vulnerable, and her gates will be wide open to enemies.

outline.heading: The Devouring Judgment and Scattered People
outline.description: The destruction is likened to a devouring fire and swarms of locusts, with leaders and captains fleeing and the people scattered. The wound is grievous and beyond healing, provoking rejoicing among those who hear of Nineveh’s fall.

application: Recognize that God’s judgment against sin is certain and just, encouraging believers to live in holiness and repentance.
Avoid spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry, understanding that God sees and condemns all forms of corruption and deception.
Trust in God’s sovereignty over nations and history, knowing that He will ultimately vindicate His righteousness.
Be vigilant in prayer for justice and deliverance, remembering that God opposes the proud and protects the humble.

keyVerses.text: Behold, I am against thee, saith the LORD of hosts; and I will discover thy skirts upon thy face, and I will shew the nations thy nakedness, and the kingdoms thy shame.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s direct judgment exposing Nineveh’s shame and moral corruption before all nations.

keyVerses.text: And it shall come to pass, that all they that look upon thee shall flee from thee, and say, Nineveh is laid waste: who will bemoan her? whence shall I seek comforters for thee?
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the total desolation of Nineveh and the absence of anyone to mourn or comfort her, highlighting the completeness of her judgment.

keyVerses.text: There is no healing of thy bruise; thy wound is grievous: all that hear the bruit of thee shall clap the hands over thee: for upon whom hath not thy wickedness passed continually?
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the irreversible nature of Nineveh’s punishment and the universal acknowledgment of her persistent wickedness.
